lg.head: Laisse 1
lg.l: In the springtime when all the fields
Are green again, as well as the laurel trees and bushes,
When all kinds of birds fall in love,
And for this reason sing and make lovely sounds,
So in the same way do ladies and young men
Enter gardens to seek their pleasure,
All the damsels along with their young men.
Each lady makes a garland of rose blossoms,
Thus each takes joy in the one toward whom love drives her.
At Pentecost when the new knight
Desires jousts and marvelous battles,
There was in France a most cruel king
As chronicled and told by Odinel,
Who was called King Charles Martel.
He held a great court; no one has ever seen its like.
But in one particular matter he acted as a felon,
When he cast Huon, one of his men, out from his own lands,
And sent him to find Lucifer and
To seek tribute from Hell,
Just so that he could possess noble-hearted Ynide.

lg.head: Laisse 2
lg.l: Listen, [my] lords (may God bless you!),
To my good song of great antiquity,
About the son of Louis who had France under his rule;
Charles Martel he was called during his lifetime.
He was a knight of very great renown;
Of all the territory that he held under his rule
He never lost a square foot
Owing to his pride and his bold tactics.
He had vanquished many foreigners,
So many that the whole world was
Under his rule. Even in pagan lands
They obeyed him; there was no one so bold as to refuse
The son of Louis when he sent out a command.
Whenever the king sent for his barons,
Without much trouble he could assemble a host of
Five hundred thousand well-supplied, good men,
Not counting the infantry with all the archers,
The half of which could never be reckoned.
Since the king believed himself far above others,
And greater than ever any of his ancestors,
He was more arrogant and presumptuous than any of them.
He despoiled everyone of their property and goods,
And shamed and dishonored many ladies.
For this reason he was not loved by the people;
Rather, the people of his land hated him.

lg.head: Laisse 3
lg.l: Now quiet down, and hear, [my] lords,
About Charles Martel, who was emperor
And who in his time won much honor.
But the more he won, the crueler yet he became;
There was no king or prince or duke or vavasour,
Count or marquis or baron or nobleman
Who did not serve him out of fear or out of loyalty.
One day the king had a wish and desire
To see clearly the best of his men,
[To know] which one was the most daring and valiant.
He took counsel with the count of Luxembourg,
And furthermore with Roger, the Lord of Nantes,
As to how he could see them in action.
They answered, "Have it announced everywhere
That there not remain behind anyone great or small
Who holds land, fief, or honor from the king,
That everyone come quickly to your court at Pentecost.
Let everyone bring either his daughter or his sister
Or even a cousin, or let him bring, rather, his wife;
For you will find a lord for the maidens,
And you will honor the married men:
For you could also create numerous new knights,
Dubbing many with a fine, brilliant sword.
Anyone who does not come will lose your love."
"Indeed," said Charles, "I will do this without delay."
So right away he called the public criers;
He gave the order, and they rode off
To proclaim the court called by the emperor.

lg.head: Laisse 4
lg.l: At Pentecost, after Ascension,
The court was convened, to last four months;
It was announced everywhere far and wide,
For this reason: the emperor Charles wanted
The ladies to come with their companions,
In order to honor the blonde-haired queen,
Who would hold court with ladies of renown,
Just like the court the king wished to hold with his barons.
To this feast of which we have spoken
There came such a crowd of people
That twelve crowned kings were there,
Handsomely equipped and well-supplied:
There were dukes, princes, and counts.
People came from many lands:
There was the count of Artois and the count of Soissons,
And from Luxembourg the vassal Merigon;
There was the count of Auvergne, who brought by his side
Fair Ynide of the lovely face;
Also with him he brought Berart, his good cousin,
And Baudoin the lion-hearted,
With Thomas of Flanders (both of whom were from
The same family, as we read):
Both were brothers of the lovely Ynide,
Brothers-in-law to the good vassal Huon.
The count did not come unprepared;
Rather he had with him at least two hundred companions,
All of them the best of his household.
There was Morant, and Samson,
Who was Count Huon(s seneschal.
They went straight to Paris without stopping,
And halted in the neighborhood of Saint Paul,
So we hear. After a while they found
A lodging that Ynide had been hearing about for some time,
Which was furnished with both hay and supplies,
Various provisions, and all kinds of game,
For the purpose of holding court in honor of the felon king.

lg.head: Laisse 5
lg.l: Now the count has settled into this lodging,
The very one where Count Roland has been.
To none who came there was it forbidden
To eat or drink; rather they enjoyed the full hospitality
That the good duke [Roland] traditionally offered.
So well did Count Huon maintain [the custom]
That more than a thousand poor people were fed there everyday.
There were others of gentle birth
Who also hurried to his court
As if going to the court of the king, or even better.
He was so much loved by great and small,
That no one said anything bad about him;
There was no one who wouldn't willingly suffer or die for him.
At Pentecost when the guests had eaten and drunk
At the king(s court, and the tables were taken away,
Charles Martel drew Count Huon aside,
Along with many others whom he considered his friends:
"[My] lords," he said, "I am grateful to you all
For having come here in my honor.
It has been at least ten years, thanks be to Jesus,
Since any king, Christian or infidel,
Has dared wage war against me.
If such a thing happened, I would have to
Fight and strike with naked sword.
Because of the respite we have had,
It has seemed to me that our customary skills have been lost.
For this reason I wish to hold a tournament here
For four days, in order to teach those
Who have not struck a blow in battle in a long time.
I will have them armed on the ramparts.
In my company [will be] the famous Lord Huon
And many others whom I will choose,
One hundred against a hundred others, and there we will see
Who strikes the best with a sharp sword.
What do you say?" And they all answered,
"Well said, well said, let his advice be carried out."

lg.head: Laisse 6
lg.l: The king called for his seneschal.
"Announce for me right away throughout Paris
That after the midday meal tomorrow, let all take up their arms
Who wish to prove their courage at tourneying.
Let them be armed and ready on their dark horses."
"Sire," he said, "it will be done as you wish."
The news was announced at the crossroads;
Berart, the cousin of the marquis, heard it,
As did Baudoin and Thomas the proud.
Every one of them was joyous at the news;
Berart swore to the Lord of glory
That when the battle began in the morning, no amount of money
Could hold him back from charging into it.
Thomas said, "I'll be near you the whole time."
Baudoin said, "You won(t leave me behind."
"Indeed," said Morant, "you will have my son and me [at your side]."
So many knights put themselves forward (what can I say?),
There were a hundred counts desiring
To have the honor and prize over everyone.

lg.head: Laisse 7
lg.l: The next day after dinner,
Once Huon the knight, along with baron Berart, son of John the warrior,
Had held court, there he
Had the horn blown and the drum sounded;
Those whom he sought heard it.
Those who wished to joust mounted
On their horses, completely armed.
At that point, Berart, like a good liegeman,
In order to begin the tournament, led everyone [to the field]
Under a banner decorated with a raging lion
As well as spots of red on a field of gold.
Berart addressed his men, saying, "I pray you,
At the start of the tournament charge,
O knights, call out the name 'Auvergne!'"
Each one answered, "Graciously and willingly!"
They entered the field where the king had assembled
One hundred and fifty of his best barons:
The count of Artois, Guinimer of Orléans,
Blanquin of Alemania, the prince of Soissons,
And many others whom I cannot name for you,
Who already, as it so happens, had chased two large divisions of troops
Of three hundred knights out of the tournament.
But in the main hall that day, King Charles
Stayed close to Huon the baron,
And they watched to see who might defend himself best.
On the other side, fair ladies
Climbed up high in order to see who was the fiercest.

lg.head: Laisse 8
lg.l: As soon as Berart had perceived
That those fighting in front on the field were beaten,
He pricked his horse with his sharp spurs.
He struck the count of Artois, whom he knocked off his horse.
Then Guinimer, the good duke of Orléans,
Thomas the valiant and Baudoin the feared,
Morant and Samson, who were not disconcerted,
Followed him at full speed.
Each one of them had knocked down a hundred others.
But, as a lion, which, when it is most enraged
Is feared above all smaller animals,
So exactly was the duke(s cousin.
Within a short space of time, he vanquished the whole field,
And won the prize over all others.
Charles saw it; it touched him to the core.
A black thought came to him:
"If this vassal lives for a long time,
And if Huon desires it, I shall be overthrown as king,
Because there are not two such ones within the bounds of the world.
But by my head, I will not have any tree in my kingdom
So large, so leafy, so full,
Without cutting all its branches."

lg.head: Laisse 9
lg.l: On that day the highest honor and prize
Was won by the bold and valiant Berart,
As on the following day and again on the third.
But on the fourth day, the king was hoping that
All the honor that Berart had won
Would be struck down and completely wiped out.
Armed with armor emblazoned with the fleur de lys
He entered the battle, together with the marquis
(That is, Huon, who has no hate for it)
Along with a hundred of the others whom he had chosen.
The king struck hard at Count Baudoin,
So that he knocked him off his good Moorish steed,
And next [he knocked down] Thomas the nobleman.
Before the king pulled back his bridle,
He had struck down twenty-six of their men.
But Count Huon wasn't intending
To fight against his friends
Until he saw the king getting the worst of it.
The king was watching and recognized Berart the bold;
He saw Berart and did not avoid him,
Thus they hit each other with their shields and lances
And knocked each other down [from their horses] to the ground.
Huon dismounted from his Moorish steed
And handed it to the king who leaped upon it.
Then his cousin reproached him in Auvergnois:
"Well," said Berart, "by my faith in Jesus Christ,
I [at least] shall defend the honor of my country."
Count Huon mounted another Moorish steed,
And had his cousin remount as well.
But the company of the king of the Franks
Was so completely reinvigorated at this point
That they would have defeated the Auvergnats
If it hadn't been for the bold barons, Count Huon and Berart,
Who supported them with their bright polished swords.
Charles swore by the eyes in his face
That now he wanted to test Lord Huon.
Yet he knew well that as long as he wore
The standard worn by his ancestors,
Count Huon would never attack him.
For this reason, the king now made off quietly from the battle,
And slipped under a vaulted arch.
Here was a surcoat that was of dark color
With an eagle in flight painted on it,
Made all of silver that sparkled in the sun.
The king took it and put it on;
He covered his charger with the same [insignia]
As well as his curved shield.
Then he returned to the tournament that was ending in a draw.

lg.head: Laisse 10
lg.l: He returned to the tournament, this proud Caesar,
Whose heart was filled with the devil(s counsel.
He saw his people pull back and retreat
Since Huon, that gracious nobleman,
Was now on the side of those of his own house.
Charles went ahead and rode toward him as if to attack,
And struck Huon on his shield and in the face,
And with his sword would have left his peer like a dead man.
But Huon struck him back, for he didn(t recognize him at all,
So that he knocked the king off his horse to lie stretched out by the fence.
The emperor's tumble
Made his helmet fall off with a great clatter.
Huon saw him and said to himself, "Oh, alas, miserable sinner,
That I have attacked my own lord!"
Then, dismounting from his magnificent dappled horse,
He seized his sword by the blade(without hesitation(
And said to the king, "Take this, Lord Caesar,
Take vengeance on this wretched traitor
Who laid his hand where he never should have done."
The king heard him, smiled pleasantly at him and declared:
"Huon, noble brother, have no fear,
It is I who acted badly.
In my opinion, if it is not unreasonable,
He who acts foolishly should pay the consequences."

lg.head: Laisse 11
lg.l: "Huon, dear brother, have no fear;
I am glad to have had first-hand experience of your strength.
Now I know that there is no better lance in the world
Than yours; I have even more confidence in you.
Never for such a reason will you lose my friendship;
From now on, let the confusion of the tournament remain behind.
Let's return to our lodgings;
There we'll have joy and peaceful comfort."
"Willingly," said Huon, "without delay."
By order of the king, the word went out
That the tournament had been halted;
Everyone obeyed without delay.
Together with Huon the king of France returned
To the great palace; there they dismounted.
Together with all his indomitable barons
The king returned in peace and quiet.
The king gave away many horses from Konstanz,
Dappled ones and greys and many other gifts
To his barons; he honored, valued and rewarded [them]
According to their merits.

lg.head: Laisse 12
lg.l: Once the king had granted to each one
Gifts of money, horses and battle steeds,
Measures of silver, hanaps of bright gold,
Molted falcons, goshawks, and sparrowhawks,
The king ordered twelve kings to return
To their homes, where they usually lived,
Equipped with armor and war horses.
As soon as he wanted to ask them [to leave],
All they had to do was mount their horses.
They all left graciously and willingly.
The king kept with him the brave Count Huon,
The count of Artois, and his vassal Roger
From Luxembourg, the valiant Lord Aymeri,
And many others whom I cannot name for you.
The king put his arm around Huon's shoulder on the ermine collar
That he had won as the prize for the tournament,
Which the Franks and their wives were talking about.
Charles brought him along with the other barons
To go see the fair queen
Who was holding a full court with the ladies.
When she saw the emperor, she stood before [him];
She answered his greeting immediately,
And then followed it with a question:
"Sire," she said, "I request a boon of you:
Tomorrow we must celebrate the feast day
Of Saint Denis, who is our patron saint;
A great tumult, you know, goes along with it.
Now I would like to beg you, my gentle lord,
That on your part, you have it announced
That, toward the end of the feast day,
There not be anyone so bold, either foot soldier or knight,
As to find himself along the road to the sanctuary:
If he is a foot soldier, he'll put his feet up,
And if he is noble, he'll go rejoice [somewhere].
The reason for all this is that I wish to celebrate tomorrow, sire,
And offer dinner to Huon(s wife,
And then we want to go see the saint(s feast celebration,
And do not wish to be bothered by any of the men."
Hearing her, the king began to laugh heartily.
"What do you say, Lord Huon, dear brother?"
"By my faith, sire, this request must be granted."
Charles answered, "By the faith I owe Saint Peter,
Since you are agreeable, a curse on whoever wants to forbid it."

lg.head: Laisse 13
lg.l: The king granted the favor freely;
On Saint Denis's feast day
Charles and the other knights went together
To see the celebration, and then they returned.
The next day, if the book is not lying,
The most fair queen attended
Along with the lovely Ynide,
As did many others whose names I can(t recall for you.
The ladies were clothed in a similar manner and appearance:
In a red wool cloth that one can buy.
Two by two the ladies went hand in hand,
And the young maidens in the front sang.
Others accompanied the song on the viol
So beautifully and graciously
That their singing seemed to descend from the angels.

lg.head: Laisse 14
lg.l: This is how the ladies and young girls proceeded
On their way to see the celebration along with many pilgrims;
The queen was first of all,
And Ynide followed her, walking just behind,
Dressed in rosy wool.
The blond locks of her hair spread across her shoulders;
Her head was crowned with a circlet of gold worth a fortune,
And she wore an imported silk belt.
She had firm little breasts,
A dainty mouth, evenly-pointed teeth,
And large laughing grey-blue eyes with a lively expression
Like that of a falcon when it takes game.
There was no man so ill, were he even at death's door,
Who would have been happy with any other medicine
Once he had seen this noble lady.

lg.head: Laisse 15
lg.l: Ynide was dressed in such great beauty,
That all the others were nothing compared to her.
Let(s leave her for now. Let me remind you
About King Charles who wanted to sleep
In his vaulted chamber, when there befell him
A disgrace that could not have been foreseen.
Here a minstrel, whose name was Saudin,
Came freely into his chamber without constraint;
He saw the king lying on his sheet of woven gold.
Saudin greeted Charles, singing,
"What are you doing, your majesty, arise without delay!
Your household is sleeping now; let's ride through the streets,
Let each of us change into a costume,
Let's go see the ladies who have come
To your court; many of them have come out outdoors,
Therefore their beauty will be visible to us today."
"Indeed," said the king, "so help me God,
I will see them, whoever may think it foolish."

lg.head: Laisse 16
lg.l: The king took off his old clothes,
And dressed himself in his brightest colors.
The old clothes he gave to Saudin the minstrel,
And together they mounted their ambling horses.
They took neither a road nor even a path;
Rather they rode so quickly without delay through a little valley,
That they arrived within a bowshot,
Near Saint Denis. Making offerings of gold,
The queen was already in the main church.
The king approached creeping in the shadow of a tree
In order to hide himself from everyone, great and humble.
He pulled his hood down over his eyes;
He pretended to be dozing at that hour.
When he put his hand on the minstrel(s shoulder,
He kept his eyes seemingly closed, but he could see the whole time,
And looked to see which lady possessed the most beauty.
Then the clear-faced Ynide appeared,
Carrying a rose blossom in her hand.
She smelled it often; it had a lovely odor.
But the minstrel said to the emperor,
"Look, look, she is the most noble of all."
Charles saw her and directed his steed toward her,
Saying a greeting, "May the Redeemer
Save such a lady! And I believe most fervently
That when our Creator formed you
He had no other task to do.
But a lady arrayed in such beauty
Would be cruel not to feel love.
And I beseech you, for your honor,
To bestow on me that flower you are carrying.
I will keep it, and out of love for you,
I will be your loyal servant
Under the conditions you will now hear."

lg.head: Laisse 17
lg.l: When the duchess heard this speech,
She knew exactly what he wanted and expected;
She knew who he was but pretended not to.
Like one whose heart was guarded,
She responded wisely and courteously:
"Noble knight, a thousand thanks to you
For what you say, and I beg and entreat you
To bestow your love in such a place,
Where you might expect a reward.
A man who serves without any satisfaction(
It seems to me that his love is ill-placed.
Love such a lady, noble lord, I beg you,
Who can retain you as her loyal friend.
I have no desire to love you or indeed anyone else
Except for the one
Whom God himself commanded and decreed that I love:
The count of Auvergne, that nobleman,
For the two of us are joined together in marriage.
The flower I possess, I tell you most truly,
I shall keep it as long as I am alive,
And shall give it to the count, my husband,
When I return, because I took it from him."

lg.head: Laisse 18
lg.l: Charles, who was dismayed, heard her.
"Lady," he said, "do not take this to be ill-breeding,
Because I do not ask this of you with bad intent.
But Love wants to have lordship
Over lovers devoted to each other.
When a man serves with a willing heart, without foolishness,
His service demands that his effort be rewarded.
Now grant me the colorful rose;
I will be joyful for the rest of my life,
And you yourself will be all the more beautiful for having done it:
A lady who has never accepted love even a little
Is not worth the lees [of a wine cask].
A man or a woman in love
Is worth much more and is made more gracious for it."
"Sire," said Ynide, "may God bless me,
But one would be foolish to pour out one(s love
On someone who loves him not at all.
Let me be, I beg of you, noble lord,
And return to your own road."
"Lady," he said, "We shall keep you company."
The duchess replied, "I cannot keep silent any longer;
When a king of France rushes into foolishness,
He's wrong to reproach others for behaving foolishly.
When Count Huon returns, I will tell him
All that you have confessed to me.
If your desire pleases him,
I shall incline myself to your will."
The king heard her, but didn(t know any longer what to say.
When the king heard her answer, he acted
Exactly like a frightened maiden
Who, when she agrees to something and then regrets
Her mortal error, believes herself betrayed:
He turned about-face and departed from her.

lg.head: Laisse 19
lg.l: The king entered his chamber quietly;
There was a most opulent bed
Where the king sat down, feeling how his heart ached,
For his mind was full of conflicting and crazy thoughts
Because of what he had said to Ynide.
He knew truly that if she told her lord [Huon] all about it,
He would never love him again.
And on the other hand, he was very much afraid,
Because Count Huon and his wife were
Of excellent character and loved by all his people.
He also knew very well that the people hated him,
And that if Huon wanted to, he could seize his kingdom!
Then, [the king] so burned in his heart for the love of Ynide,
That he told himself lies in this way
Saying that he would rather be the count of Auvergne
[In order] to have Ynide entirely for one night,
Than to have his own entire realm and everything he possessed.
But he dared not reveal it to anyone,
Nor did he yet know
How he could accomplish what he wanted.

lg.head: Laisse 20
lg.l: Charles Martel thought a lot about this(
About how he would possess the duchess and get rid of the count;
If he wanted to take her by force, he saw clearly he could not.
The count had lots of friends and fine knights,
For a better man than he one could never find.
Therefore it would be necessary to conquer him subtly,
Employing trickery and shrewdness.
The king declared himself unfortunate and didn(t know how he would do it:
"This man alone can seize the country if he so wishes,
And I see his noble wife will finish me off.
She is worthy and wise, nor will she ever give in to me;
For no wealth in the world will she betray her husband.
It was in an evil hour that I saw her; alas that she was ever born!"
The more he thought about it, the worse it seemed.
Because of the grief and rage that he felt,
He tossed and turned on his bed.
The king pondered the matter
From every which way, how he could accomplish it.
The more he thought about it, the less he knew what to do,
And he dared not reveal what was wrong with him to anyone,
How his heart was crazed by the love that beset it.
He said that he would die if he couldn't accomplish [his purpose].
For three full days he spoke to no one,
Nor did any porter dare open to anyone.
Everyone wondered about this;
Everyone wanted to go back to his own land,
But they didn(t dare as long as the king prohibited it,
For each one feared the anger of the king.

lg.head: Laisse 21
lg.l: After the fourth such day passed hurriedly,
Many of the barons didn't have the courage
To enter the chamber where the king lay
In order to ask or request anything,
So greatly did they fear their lord.
But a minstrel whom the king loved very much,
Whom many people called Saudin,
Finally entered by everyone's mutual consent.
He went up to the bed where the king lay,
And found him moaning and making great lament
To himself, like a suffering woman.
At his feet, the courtier placed himself on his knees,
And said, "My lord, what are you afraid of?
In this earthly world there is nothing you might desire
That you couldn(t have right away;
Without much trouble, you will have it completely.
You are the ruler, and everything depends on you;
Nor will anyone oppose your orders.
If anyone did so, he would soon repent it;
Were anyone to say or do anything at court,
Justice would be rendered at your command;
And don't you worry about it.
Show your courage bravely to everyone!"

lg.head: Laisse 22
lg.l: "Come on," said Saudin, "by God above, my lord,
Don(t lament or show rancor,
There is no man alive whom you should fear.
Take heart and show the strength of an emperor,
Who renders justice when men commit crimes.
Tell what this is about to everyone great and small;
If this is handled wisely, you shall accrue more honor,
For we will advise you as to the best thing to do."
At this last speech the king sighed and wept,
Then he looked up; there was no one there besides them.
The king thought that he might reveal his love
To the minstrel. He was always the right one in such an affair
For carrying messages and gathering information.
He would not reveal to anyone the hatred he felt for Huon the count:
He knew how to keep things to himself,
For which reason it will be evident later, because he will harm [Huon].
Thus the king thought that he might advance his project;
So he said to Saudin, "I love and value you highly,
But can I trust you?" "Indeed, my good sir,
There is nothing in this world, if I can have the opportunity,
That I wouldn't do for you, if death holds off long enough.
Go ahead and say what you have to say, for I have never been a deceiver.
I will always do what you wish as best I can."

lg.head: Laisse 23
lg.l: "Saudin," said the king, "Now, listen to me concerning this matter;
I will tell you something about it. But it must be in secret(
Be careful not to talk about it to anyone except to those you absolutely must
From here on out. Now help me with this,
And if you do you shall have a fine reward for it.
I am in love with such a creature, now you'll hear,
Such that I don(t believe I can bear the weight of grief
If I don't get her, thanks to God or thanks to you.
I know it isn't appropriate; that is what weighs so much on me.
But I cannot change how I feel; I have never had such a great desire!
If I cannot have what I long for, I believe I shall surely die;
No other cure could there be for this."
The minstrel said, "I foresee great loss
Because from a woman can come much trouble.
After all, you are clearly king and lord;
No one can oppose you, so I believe.
And if someone did do so, within a month
He would repent of it and come back to you right away,
Or else flee like a wretch into hiding.
Have no fear now, [my] cherished lord. So, recount it all to me;
I promise to think about a good plan for you now."
After this speech the king felt comforted.

lg.head: Laisse 24
lg.l: Then he said to Saudin, "My friend, listen to this:
It is love for Ynide, Huon's wife, whom everyone saw at the feast,
That has so wounded my heart!
I am sure that there is no other such woman in all of Christendom,
Nor will anyone ever find one more worthy or wise,
And loyal to her lord(everyone loves both of them very much.
Moreover he is feared wherever he goes;
Everyone speaks of his chivalric qualities.
Everyone loves him, he has friends everywhere;
For this reason I am wary of them; if the proud lady suspects anything,
This undertaking will earn no profit,
And there could even be great evil to come out of it.
Alas, sinner that I am! My heart will expire from grief.
I cannot imagine any counsel that can help my heart recover."
But Saudin said, "Don(t despair anymore about it:
If it please God, there will be good counsel.
Do just as you are told:
If you have friends whom your heart trusts,
And who you know will not fail you for any reason,
Send for them. Your request will be
That they protect your honor as best they can.
I will explain the thing to them in your presence;
If this doesn(t work, there is no other advice that will.
Do this now, otherwise you will never start."
The king trusted what Saudin said;
He sent word to those of his council in whom he had the most confidence.

lg.head: Laisse 25
lg.l: The emperor Charles sent for twelve counts;
Each of them was wise, as was completely proper for them.
Once they were gathered before him, they kneeled down,
And Charles appealed to them, welcoming them.
He implored them to give him good counsel
About how they wanted him to accomplish this affair;
And if in any way they let him down, despite his desire,
Right away, they would all be disinherited.
At this point he told it all(
Why he had been so afflicted;
He explained the whole matter of his love for Ynide,
But he kept quiet for now the other aspect of the matter.
When they had heard it all, they were very alarmed,
Everyone spoke at once, predicting disaster or lecturing.
They looked at one another, for each feared the count;
People, both the foolish and the wise, usually spoke only well of him.
But the king admonished them:
"What do you think about this? Shall I die because of you lords,
Or indeed shall I gain what I desire?"
"My lord," they said, "these are strange doings;
We can(t see this being accomplished without great danger."

lg.head: Laisse 26
lg.l: "Fair sire," said together the twelve counts,
"We see clearly that this is a grievous matter for you;
Several people will die accomplishing this task
But neither I nor anyone else here can refuse;
What you request, we must carry through.
The lady is very wise; the friends of her lord will never fail her:
They would rather die for her.
And the count is very brave; there is no one like him in the world.
If he becomes aware of this matter, they will defend themselves.
You know that they will wage a great war against you because of it.
And then we cannot imagine any good advice to give you."
"I actually have one," the jongleur answered him,
"If you will all accept what I'll say."
Each one pledged his faith and then encircled him:
They will approve of all that he will say,
And after his speech, they will carry it out
If they know any way of doing so.

lg.head: Laisse 27
lg.l: Saudin continued, "Now, listen, [my] lords,
The good count has such renown that
If he promises a thing, he will never be proved a liar;
He will always defend his honor to the death
To accomplish whatever he can.
Let the high emperor send for him;
Before anyone then reveals the story of the plan to him,
Have him swear an oath with complete willingness
That he will maintain his honor in good faith,
Then he will fulfill the honor of Your Lordship,
Nor will he ever cause you any harm.
Having promised thus, he will be committed for sure;
He will surely be loyal, as you will be able to see.
Once you will have gotten all this from the count,
Then you will tell him that he is to be an ambassador.
Without any delay or rest,
He is to leave right away for the worst dwelling place in the world,
That is, to Hell, where everyone suffers,
Where he is to say that, in your name, he asserts possession of the kingdom of shadow
[And] all the fortresses appertaining thereto,
And he can hold [for you] all the land around there.
Before he returns from that land
Let him speak to him who is the greatest of them all,
And, without any rest or respite, let him find out what he must from him.
If [the Devil] wants to remain your friend, peacefully or amicably:
Let him give you the tribute that he has always kept from you;
If not, then you must challenge all his people.
Then you will levy your biggest army,
And seek him out as much for honor as for valor;
He would not escape either to a castle or a tower,
Even if he were a flying bird.
You would know the tricks and arts better than [the devil]
So that he will be brought right away to your justice.
I don't want to stir up your distress again:
As God in Heaven is Lord of all virtues,
And ruler of all the many angels, archangels and dominions,
Just so you are our lord and the strength
Of the entire world and all that belongs to it.
We truly see that Hell was exiled to earth;
By rights he should be its shepherd;
In this enterprise I believe today that [Huon] will win.
As soon as he travels there, let him lay waste to the land all around.
You will have, sire, his service for all his possessions;
He will send such tribute as is fitting to your honor.
Send then, sire, for Huon the count;
Make him swear before [knowing] this task;
If he will swear it, you are safe from then on,
In this matter he will get going without delay.
Once he's far away for a long enough time,
Send then for the lady, order her to come to court;
Then you will easily be able to have her."
Everyone cried out, "That is indeed worthy advice,
We could never give you better!
Let it be done like that; we recommend it now,
For it pleases us, fair king."
"Yes, indeed," he then answered,
"Let there be no delay in carrying this out."

lg.head: Laisse 28
lg.l: The treason was set up; the king had accepted it;
He called for Count Huon to come see him right away.
Huon came to the king and stood before him;
"My lord," he said, "I am here for you.
If there is anything I can do that would please you,
Provided that my position is not injured,
That can reasonably be done and attained,
I am ready to obey you in everything."
At this speech the king took him by the hand,
Raised him up and seated him by himself.
Laughing, he said, "Dear, sweet, gentle friend,
I don(t know of any man living better than you,
Braver, wiser, of more worth.
After God and compared to other people,
By my faith, I love you more than a brother or near relation.
I will explain the matter to you right away that causes me to lament:
You must make a journey for me; I know no one more valiant,
Nor one in whom I can place a more solemn trust.
Is it thus, dear brother, as I am saying?"
"Tell [me what it is], [my] dear, fair lord, and [I will do it,] if indeed I am able."
"Well, then," the king said to him, "first you must swear;
Afterward I will tell you what I have in mind.
Then you will make every effort to carry out my order,
And right now I swear to you as a loyal king
To act always for your benefit."
"Sire," said the count, "and I am happy with this."

lg.head: Laisse 29
lg.l: Right after Huon spoke thus,
The king had holy relics brought in,
And the count kneeled, weeping with great emotion,
Devotedly praying to God to keep him from evil torment;
Because he would go with a well-intentioned heart,
Without intending evil, nor working toward evil,
[He prayed] that God might have pity on him before his mortal end,
That his soul might never be damned for anything he did,
And that afterward he might remain safe and sound and alive.
With great devotion he kissed the relics;
To please the king, he pronounced his oath
Right away and in the exact way that it was told him to do,
And he promised truly to execute without any trickery
All that the king would now tell him to do.
And he swore all this quickly.

lg.head: Laisse 30
lg.l: The oath was pronounced, and the king explained
Then the whole road that lay before him
From one end to the other. Both were sure
That as long as he was alive, he would maintain [the king's] honor.
But as for Huon, know this, it troubled him severely;
He knew well that he had accepted a mission that could not be accomplished
By any mortal man however long he might live.
It is an impossible thing, the holy writings speak of it:
Hell was made for sinners for when their souls deserve it,
And to confound those who fell from Heaven.
The noble count laid out many arguments
So that the king might drop this matter, for he could perform some other deed for him,
And this was a lost cause that no man could accomplish.
"Hey," said the king, "my good count, what are you saying?
Isn(t Hell somewhere on earth? It is located somewhere on earth;
Just as God is in Heaven up above exercising his power,
So also the land here below all around is mine.
Everything must obey me, wherever it is on land:
Water, flying birds, and all the beasts there are,
Every single thing on earth has its place;
It all belongs to me, have no doubt of that.
I accord most of it to those who submit to me.
One who doesn(t accept my sovereignty over the earth is committing a great error;
That one can indeed say that he will have to pay for it.
I have been asleep up until now,
Presently I am awake; from here on out we'll see
Whether anyone will, by his own power, keep any part of what belongs to me."

lg.head: Laisse 31
lg.l: "Huon, dear brother," said the emperor,
Never will anyone hold a foot of land or a dwelling
By force; know it for sure,
For men say to me that there is a greater kingdom
Established on earth, both on hill and in dale,
And that is the infernal domain.
Now you will carry my letter and my seal;
I want to know(be it for good or for evil(
Whether this felon Lucibial will bow to me.
If it turns out that he won(t, he will face a deadly war;
But if that kingdom will obey me, we shall have the others as well.
I need say no more to you, my loyal, noble friend;
You will certainly accomplish the task; your sanctity [is] such
That I have more faith in you than in any man of flesh.
Good sense, sobriety, prowess, all reside equally in you,
And have taken up residence there.
There is no better vassal than you in the world
Who can carry my seal in this matter;
You can count on my loyal affection,
And that of all these barons together.
Everyone praises you to me, no one nominates anyone
But you. Carry my message to the infernal domain,
To the cruel felon."

lg.head: Laisse 32
lg.l: When the Count Huon understood what the king wanted
And that he had no choice but to go,
Whatever he might say, [the king] would not accept his reasons.
Since he had sworn it, he had to keep his word
To do all that he had promised, if he didn(t want to be forsworn.
Otherwise he would be treated as a criminal and declared a liar for sure;
Then, in the king's court he would be without honor,
And still greater evil could indeed result from all this.
The count reflected deeply and saw no hope anywhere;
Between going and remaining, he didn(t know which was better.
He put himself in God(s hands, and tears came into his eyes.
Then he said to the king, "I will do as you ask.
I would not want your honor to suffer on my account.
I shall go seek what, indeed, no man alive
Has ever attained, so one says, be it foolishness
And untenable, or a fable not to be believed.
I am going to my death, I will never return;
I am seeking something impossible, I know it well.
Still, I shall try to the best of my ability to do it as long as I have the leisure;
If it pleases God I will not be a liar.
I commend my wife to your keeping, and all my heritage;
I don(t ask for more than a month of time to prepare,
Then I will leave on my search, by Saint Gregory."

lg.head: Laisse 33
lg.l: "My lord," said Sir Huon the count,
"I will do my best, but this is folly;
I am going to my death if God does not come to my aid."
And the king quickly reassured him about the matter,
Saying cheerfully that he would return safe and sound,
And that a fine reward would be waiting for him for his labor;
And, by his soul, his wife and honor could be entrusted to him [the king].
The count then bowed down and kissed his feet.
"I trust you, lord king," said the good count,
And the king that day swore most vehemently
That he would take good care of [Huon's] land and his wife.
Alas! What an evil oath this traitor king made!
For this sin his soul will be still today in damnation,
If he hasn(t repented with a totally true heart.
I don't believe it happened, even on his last day,
That he ever improved; on the contrary, he became even worse.
Let the Devil keep him who was his servant!

lg.head: Laisse 34
lg.l: The discussion was over and everything settled,
From both sides they pledged and swore:
Each to keep his promises without fail.
The king blessed the count who turned to leave.
He showed no mournful face to anyone,
But he couldn(t help thinking about it.
He said to his barons, "Have your ladies mount up;
We all have leave to go, let us take advantage of that;
Let us return to our land; there we shall stay for a while.
I must carry out a great task for the king;
And now, for everything you hold dear,
No one must ask to know the truth;
Soon enough, in time, you will know, even though I would rather you didn(t."
They said nothing, and very soon they all set out.
The count rode all day and all night
Until they came to Auvergne, his good city.
He entered the town and dismounted at the base of the stairs.
For two days the count said not a word,
Not even speaking to his wife as he was normally wont to do.
"Oh, God," said Ynide, "could he have been watching
When the king Charles Martel was making that request of me?
It was foolish of me not to have told him about it when it first happened;
But God knows the truth, and sees my fidelity,
And knows I concealed it all from my own dear lord
Because I didn(t want at that time to put hostility between them.
Whatever may be the result, I will ask him now
Why he has shown himself so angry toward me."
So on the third day, the lady spoke.
With her were her brothers-in-law, who were very sensible:
Thomas and Baudoin, who loved her very much,
And her two nephews, who were of a good age,
Called Samson and Rainer,
And her cousin Berart, that fearsome vassal:
All of them halted together before the count.
They addressed him graciously and begged him most earnestly
To reassure his people who were quite uneasy,
Saying that it would be best for him to tell them what he intended to do;
He should take good counsel, nor should he be afraid.
They spoke about it and begged him so repeatedly
That he promised to do what they wished.
Then they were reassured, and he sent for his council.
He spoke of and discussed many matters,
But he hid everything regarding his great task.
Rather he called for setting up a great court:
"Let it go on for ten days, or even nine, by my faith,
And everyone will prepare as best he can
To honor me simply with his goodness.
Then it will be necessary for me to leave on the king(s business,
On which I have been sent and dispatched by the king himself.
At that moment, when I will be separated from you,
Then everyone, both great and small, will know the truth."

lg.head: Laisse 35
lg.l: The court was publicly announced and was known both far and wide;
Everyone was very pleased to come.
People came from many foreign lands,
And the noble count of Auvergne received them very well.
They were provided with every possible pleasure and joy.
As far as the count was concerned, nothing was hidden
Except for one thing alone that everyone was waiting for at the dinner.
Everyone was surely coming to the court being held,
Where each person was happily received.
During that time the court filled up;
The people passed time in the vaulted hall.
So welcome were they made in the hall,
That the hour of terce passed as the sun turned on its course.
The people washed their hands and sat down to table.

lg.head: Laisse 36
lg.l: At once the barons all sat down at table,
As well as the poor people. Everyone was served
In honor of God in whom the count put his trust,
Such that the food was served around many times;
Everyone ate what pleased him best.
Count Huon remained standing the whole time;
He himself ate nothing, instead the baron served others.
[Now] hear what an adventure God destined for the count:
The local people called out in loud voices
That a pilgrim was coming up the road,
And that by the look of him he seemed completely exhausted.
When the count heard it, he called over one of his young men:
"Go quickly," he said, "take a horse, it(s faster,
Bring the pilgrim to me as quickly as possible.
Put him on the horse and come at a fast pace."
And [the young man] did exactly as he was ordered.

lg.head: Laisse 37
lg.l: The young man left, once he had heard the order from his lord;
He mounted a horse without much delay.
He rode with such strength and speed
That he soon came up to the pilgrim in the shade of a tree.
The pilgrim did not greet him at all, nor did the young man greet him,
But rather said, "You whoreson porter,
On whose account a grand court has been disturbed.
Everyone would have eaten by now and started the jousting
Along with many other entertainments,
And you have disturbed all that with your delay."
He grabbed him by the hair and jerked him around;
He slapped him several times and then said, "Get up right away
And mount behind me; don(t you dare complain.
If you utter a word about this, before daybreak
You will die at my hands, so help me God!"
Whether he wanted to or not, the pilgrim promised that day,
That he would say nothing to any man born of woman.
But if Huon(s servant had really known
What thing he was bringing through the wall of a tower,
Never ever would he have gone even a step with him.
Had he truly known that it was a treacherous devil,
They would have chased him away. [The pilgrim] had come to the court
In order to lead into error Huon, that good count,
Because of their desire for his death.
If God, our Lord and Redeemer, doesn(t take care,
The Devil plans to cause dishonor to many people.
For this reason he doesn(t yet want to avenge his shame;
Rather he thinks to do something even worse to someone else.

lg.head: Laisse 38
lg.l: They went straight to the court together;
Then [the pilgrim] dismounted and came before Huon.
The baron embraced him and took him by the hand;
He saw that he was weak, so he placed him beside him,
Because others refused to have anything to do with him.
[Huon] gave him water, but [the pilgrim] was silent and mute;
He spoke not a word to Huon.
A round table was placed before him
Piled with meat and good bread,
And spiced wine that would please anyone.
Huon said to the pilgrim, "My very good friend,
Eat, in the name of Jesus, all that pleases you."
Then the count made the sign of the cross over the food.
When the devil saw this, he could bear no more:
The table, the food, the meat(from where it was,
He caused it to fly up into the air and out the window,
So that the food was scattered every which way.
With great fury he left, crying as loudly as he could,
"Well, noble count of Auvergne, woe to you!
You have tricked me for your own true salvation,
And here I truly thought I had deceived you,
And after all nothing has damaged your court.
But because of the name of the sovereign whom you have mentioned,
I can have no power over you.
I will go back to Hell, where I came from.
You, on the other hand, will go where you have promised to go,
To seek what is not worth a straw.
Great suffering shall you have and great tribulation.
If that Lord (whom you love so much) doesn't take care of you,
You will die on the journey, miserable wherever you go.
Others will be joyful and you will be bitterly disappointed.
I have no more to say to you; I have said too much already."
He left there immediately, for he stuck to his route;
He went quickly ahead so that he arrived in Hell.
He had stayed too long, and was badly received.
No one removed anything from that food,
Because it was consecrated in the name of Jesus.
It will return to the place from which it was taken,
As the story will explain and you will hear.

lg.head: Laisse 39
lg.l: You have heard, [my] lords, about the great marvel
That truly happened at Huon's court.
The people were frightened and becoming more so.
They didn't know what to think; everyone waited,
No one seemed able to eat anymore.
But the noble Count Huon went around cheering everyone up,
Circulating among them and preaching comfort.
Then he said to them, "[My] lords, be reassured;
Don(t let this incident cause you any fear."
He made the sign of the cross over the food, then said cheerily:
"Eat now, [my] lords, in the name of God the omnipotent,
For after the meal we will talk further."
With these words everyone grew ever more heartened,
And then ate to their satisfaction.
But Count Huon of Auvergne sought no great honors of the table
Except for a quarter measure of bread, which was enough to satisfy his hunger,
And some water which he drank to satisfy his thirst;
Such food had been enough for him for a long time.
To tell the truth, he ate that way intentionally,
Such that everyone marveled at him;
People believed his life to be rather saintly.
Everyday when night came he mortified his flesh.
It is not up to me to tell about all the good he did,
Scarcely anyone would believe what I say;
He led a life like a hermit and of great penitence.
He said prayers every day; he was never lax in that practice
Of saying the Office of the Virgin and doing good works.
But I will stop talking of this now, and we'll talk later.
When the court finished the meal they washed up.

lg.head: Laisse 40
lg.l: After the meal, Count Huon spoke
To many of his people who stayed on there;
He explained many things to them,
About all that he thought would occur,
And what they should do when these happened.
After this, he told them about his painful dispute,
How Charles Martel had entrusted him with the great task.
With his barons, who always advised him,
He explained the whole affair, he hid nothing from them:
"I am well aware of my part in this and am really furious,
But it cannot be otherwise; it will be as God pleases,
For nothing in the world would I be forsworn.
I will never devalue loyalty;
As long as I am alive, I will be faithful.
One thing I beg of you; when I will have left,
You will not let yourselves be greatly afflicted by my absence.
It's not worth it, rather it would be harmful;
Keep up your spirits as best you can.
Pray for me to Jesus, who brought Lazarus back to life,
That he help me accomplish that which I must set off to do:
Jesus will bring it to its end when it pleases him.
I commend you all to God. The time approaches
For me to set off on this quest with no idea how long it will take.
Never will a living man, I believe, see me again,
And I don't know what road this wretch will take:
I'll slip out quietly, asking my way here and there."
Once he had said this, the laments became so intense
That there was indeed no heart so hard among those listening to him
That they would be able to keep themselves from weeping for a long time,
Not even the count of Auvergne himself was able at that point to refrain.
When Ynide heard him, she fainted away from the pain of it;
The count, seeing her faint, wept out of pity.

lg.head: Laisse 41
lg.l: When the good count(s wife had returned to consciousness,
She said, "Oh, sire, will you leave me now
When you were given to me to be my companion?
I never thought I would come to such a pass
In which a separation would occur in a faithful marriage
Or that I might remain a widow while my lord was still living in this world.
Sire, I cannot bear it, nor can I keep hidden any longer
The fact that I am the reason of your being sent on this journey.
Because of me you go to your death, but let us advise you
That you make the better of the two choices before you:
Either you begin a war against Charles,
Or you cut off my head with your sword, there at your side;
Then you will be quit of the treacherous road you are on.
[My] lord, you need to know that the day we were celebrating
The feast of the venerable Saint Denis in a procession,
The king, [having] changed into a disguise with a hooded cape,
And Saudin went to see the ladies with blond hair.
He called me over and made such requests,
That before he would receive them from me, I would rather be burnt to ashes.
This is the reason, [my] lord, why he is sending you off to the eternal prison.
I didn’t want to tell you in order not to start a quarrel,
But I can hide it no longer, when we see ourselves in such a situation;
As soon as you will have left home,
He will besiege us all around."
The duchess recounted everything to him, with every possible detail
Of what the king had told her. Huon sat with his head bowed.

lg.head: Laisse 42
lg.l: When Huon heard her, he began to think
That everything Ynide said was from a desire to deflect him from his purpose
And keep him from leaving on this journey.
Just like one who is wise, he began to remember
When he had read Caton as a young schoolboy:
"You absolutely mustn't believe a wife rashly or easily;
Frequently a woman hates the one whom her husband has loved."
Anger overtook him; he lashed out with a kick
That knocked her down hard onto the floor
So that he made her belly burst in her body.
But, when he saw her fallen and unconscious on the floor,
He was filled with pity, and he went over to help her up.
He said to her, weeping, "Have no fear, wife,
I will not leave you yet; I know how to make all the arrangements
For all my business, so you have little reason to worry."
The count ordered his people to carry her to bed.
He then gathered to him first Berart, then Thomas the warrior,
Baudoin and Morant, and Samson his squire.
"[My] lords," said the count, "I want to make my will,
For tonight I must leave you.
Berart, noble cousin," said the count in tears,
"I leave in your hands Auvergne and my wife.
More than any man in the world, I hold you most dear,
For the two of us were engendered by two brothers.
If you were ever to fail me, I don(t know whom I could trust.
Thomas and Baudoin will be useful to you;
They will always be there for you to help their sister.
As for Morant and Samson, who are my men-at-arms,
I wish to leave them two cities of my realm.
For up to seven years you must wait for me;
If you do not see me return within that amount of time,
Know, my good friends, that I will never return.
I commend you all to God." Then he went to bed,
Placing himself near his wife, lying alongside her.

lg.head: Laisse 43
lg.l: That night the noble count lay next to his lady;
He treated her affectionately and comforted her,
Saying that if it pleased God he would come back soon,
And that Berart, his brother, would never neglect her.
If the king thought to act foolishly, he would defend her,
And he himself would return within seven years, if it so pleased God.
So many things did the count say to calm her that she fell asleep.
And when the hour of midnight sounded,
Count Huon arose; he couldn't bear to wake the worthy lady.
He dressed himself without asking for his squire;
He also put on all his armor, and then didn(t tarry;
He came over to Ynide lying on the bed and watched her sleeping;
He saw her face splotched with the tears she had shed;
Weeping, the count said, "I truly believe and cannot proclaim publicly
That our faithful union shall henceforth be broken in two.
You shall remain here; but this wretch doesn(t know
Where to go, nor where he will lodge at night.
Now I pray to the one who created the world
That He have mercy on us, and I truly believe that He will,
And that He will walk with both of us."
He bent over her and kissed her very gently,
Then he raised his hand and made the sign of the cross three times over her.
He left the room without remaining any longer,
Went to his horse and mounted.
Thus he left his lands without taking any leave of anyone;
And chose the road that led straight to Hungary.
When the morning came, Ynide woke up;
When she didn(t find her lord, she beat herself so
That it was truly by a little that she didn't kill herself.
Berart came to her and comforted her,
For Ynide trusted him more than anyone else.
They then held a council to have Auvergne
Build up its fortifications and food supplies
In order that these would not fail them for seven years.
Thus they did as they deemed best.

lg.head: Laisse 44
lg.l: Count Huon had left his lands,
And had also left his people weeping for him.
From the great joy his court had felt, everything turned into affliction;
Everyone wept and sighed for their lord;
The more they tried to hold it in, the more they wept.
But more then any of the others, the most deeply sorrowful one of all
Was their lady, who was overcome with distress:
The attempts of brother or baron to comfort her were of no use.
Because of her lord, she often fell into a faint,
Saying, "Death, what are you doing?" when she got up,
"Now love your companion! I wish to live no longer."
Every day she weeps, no one can help her.
But I will leave this subject(let's talk about Huon,
Who was riding toward Hungary as fast as he could spur his horse on.
Never had this good man been so sad and pensive,
But above all, he didn't forget this,
To begin a psalm that we find in the psalter:
Keep steady my steps. All the way to the end,
He recited it in its entirety with great feeling.
He kept himself from wrath, and from other vices of the world;
Often he beseeched God to grant him and others pardon,
And that Christendom remain in peace and in the right,
And that God help him find the kingdom of Hell.

lg.head: Laisse 45
lg.l: Count Huon had set himself on the road,
And on he rode, in the name of Jesus, day after day,
From land to land, on his horse with the flowing mane,
Until finally he came to the land of Hungary,
He dismounted at the foot of the great palace.
Then he asked where he might find the king of Hungary.
A man told him that he was in the vaulted hall of his palace.
The nobleman mounted his horse again without waiting another moment;
He found the king who was holding council,
And [Huon] approached him when he recognized him.
He greeted the king who had finished his discourse;
The king recognized him, and received him gladly,
Saying, "Welcome, my very good and dear friend,
Why are you traveling, why have you come?
Whatever you seek, if I happen to have it,
I will give you as much of it as you want."
Huon, who had uncovered his head, thanked him;
Then he explained to him why he had set out.
The king heard him, although he did not really understand him.
He said to the count, "Brother, do not be in despair;
Whatever I have I will put at your disposal.
Very soon you will see my army:
Even without the lesser foot soldiers there are more than fifty thousand
Knights, [each] with lance and naked sword,
[And] beyond, archers, [each] with a bow stretched back to his neck."
Suddenly the king sat down;
"Seek nothing from your lord from now on;
This miscreant king has done wrong to many people,
And we will certainly absolve you and others
For the evil he has done; he will have sold your lives dearly."
"Heavens, sire," said Huon, "I would never consent to that;
I don't want anyone to be condemned on my account,
That could not occur without great harm done.
For a long time I have been his servant and he my lord and dear friend;
I will not renounce obeying completely
What he sent me to do even unto death,
Whether it's right or for wrong, because I am the servant of Jesus.
Though I have learned what the agreement means,
It will not be refuted by me as long as I live.
Since I swore to it, the oath that I committed to
Will not be broken by me."

lg.head: Laisse 46
lg.l: Huon said, "Sire, hear what I have to say:
I am very grateful to you for what you said.
If there's anything I can do for you of use,
I will gladly do it.
One thing I do request, good sir, and beg of you,
That you serve Charles, my rightful king,
In order not to make the journey on which I go more difficult.
You love reason, and are faithful to the king;
The king sends me as a messenger on the advice of his
Primary council; I will never refuse him anything,
Even though I know that I will find nothing there.
In other matters, one finds much strife,
Because of hope that is not worth a fig.
I know well, [my] lord, that I labor for nothing."
"Huon, noble brother," said the king right away,
"Out of love for you I will obey him."
He stayed with the king for two or three days,
Then he commended him to God and left
To go where chance led him and his horse
To whom he gave free rein,
Saying, "Go forth for the honor of the Holy Cross,
For I see no other alternative."
From land to land he traveled as he could,
For more than three and a half months, or so I believe,
He didn(t cease traveling by way of valleys, plains and hills.
I will not recount to you every single day,
But he traveled so far that he arrived in Rome.

lg.head: Laisse 47
lg.l: Once the count had left home,
And had left behind his grieving people,
Morand, who was the vassal of the lordly count,
Called for his son and said to him in secret,
"Now listen to me," he said, "my dear son,
Since my lord, who is your lord too,
Has gone away, I don(t wish to remain here.
Let us both leave tomorrow at soon as daylight appears;
We will seek our noble lord.
Know this in truth, I cannot be apart from him.
If death itself doesn't separate me from him,
Straight into Hell we will go with him;
Are you willing, my son?" And his son answered, "Yes!"
After that they did not delay for long;
They took their armor and weapons and set out on horseback.
They were off on their search through many foreign lands,
Hoping thus to find the noble count(
But I will not speak to you of this any longer,
Which you will hear all about before the end.

lg.head: Laisse 48
lg.l: Listen, [my] lords (may God bless you all!),
To a well-told tale of great renown,
Concerning Huon d(Auvergne, who took his leave
From Charles Martel, who was his sworn lord,
In order to accomplish a devilish task,
As you have heard previously in the telling of the tale.
The greatest tribulation he ever had in his life will weigh on him.
So much did he wander, the count, over the course of three and a half months,
From one land to another on this journey
That one day, before the hour of prime sounded,
He came to Rome; there he lodged
At the house of a city burgher, who served him very well,
Both him and his horse, with everything Huon could want.
Then, as a penitent, he visited many churches.
The nobleman beat his breast and prayed to God in His majesty
That He help him accomplish the task that he had begun
So that he would not be called a traitor.
Then he returned to his host, asking for permission to leave,
And the latter granted it, and commended him to God.
But before he left, [his host] spoke to him about the city
Where the pope is so that he could be confessed.
He searched for it until he found it;
Then with great reverence he threw himself at the pope(s feet.
With many tears he recited all his sins,
Begging for pardon for all he had done.
The pope absolved him; indeed he found little fault in him;
Then, once he had blessed him, he had him sit down,
For he wished to know more about his life.

lg.head: Laisse 49
lg.l: Count Huon was in before the pope,
And the pope asked him to tell him his name,
From what lineage he was and from what house.
"I can swear to you, without any error,
That in my entire life I have never seen a less sinful person.
Listen to me wisely while I advise you:
Jesus from his throne will perform wonders through you.
Tell me your situation for I desire very much to know."
So Huon told him his story, every bit of it;
When the pope had heard it, from his eyes
Tears of pity began to fall, and he said, "Ah, noble man,
Are you the one of such great renown?
Everyone speaks of you, both Poitevins and Gascons,
And many people from many regions.
No one says anything but good of you;
What could the fair-haired Charles Martel be thinking of?
Is he envious of you, that he orders you to do this,
That he wants you to seek that which doesn(t exist in this world?
This is an impossible thing, I am sure of that;
Forget about this quest, we will acquit you of it.
I will send him a message to pardon you,
That he not press you to find what no one can find.
And if he does not agree, we will excommunicate him,
And all his land we will put under interdiction!
Truly it is contrary to our faith, what he has ordered you to do."
"Oh, my lord," answered Count Huon,
"In God(s name I beg you not to do this;
We must accept everything he does as good and proper.
He was wise, and he took good and wise counsel,
Then, above all, he placed confidence in me, therefore
I am truly obliged to make an effort to accomplish his purpose,
And I insist on doing it, without any proof to the contrary.
I will never be against King Charles;
Either I will carry out his wishes, or indeed I will die;
I cannot follow any other path at this time.
I am aware of the impossibility of my task;
The things I am seeking will not be found;
May God do with me as He pleases and finds good."

lg.head: Laisse 50
lg.l: When the pope saw that he couldn(t retain him,
No matter what he said or however much he begged him,
For what he had promised, he just had to carry through,
The pope said, "Ah, God, do not let him perish!
There never was such a vassal who served his lord so,
For he goes to his death in order to remain faithful!
Ah, Huon, fair brother, I want to say to you now,
Since you are not willing to give in to our pleading and remain here,
Go then to the Holy Sepulcher in order to make an offering
And to pray; may God not deny you this,
And may He allow you still to accomplish your quest.
And I, for my part, wish to promise this:
For seven years you will be able to count on
This advantage that I will explain:
I grant you a gift (may God consent to it),
And may you be able to return one day
In fact to your lord just as you desire,
And may He grant your wish.
Now take these gifts that I will present to you;
You must never possess them in bad faith.
When you will have them on you, you will not fall,
But only if you are willing to serve God in true penitence.
This, a little cross, should really please you;
It has most truly a piece of the holy wood
On which Jesus, our Lord, was crucified."
When the count heard these words, he threw himself at the pope(s feet;
He wept tenderly, then he reached out to take the gift;
With great devotion he kissed it and drew it to himself.
After that he wrapped it up with lovely Syrian fabric,
And put it in his alms purse. He had several hosts consecrated,
Then he requested leave. The pope blessed him, saying,
"May the Lord God be with you if it please Him.

lg.head: Laisse 51
lg.l: Count Huon left the pope,
Who had granted him pardon for all of his sins,
As he would for someone who hardly had any,
And he gave him his blessing and his benediction.
So the count departed, leaving the place very early;
He mounted his horse, taking all his armor;
Once out of Rome he wandered a bit [without a precise destination].
He traveled a long time through hills and mountains,
Crossing nearly all of them going at a gallop.
If anyone asked him on any pretext
About his business, he didn't answer anyone.
Instead he moved on, he never dallied;
He traveled for a long time through hills and mountains,
Until he arrived in Sicily, but did not stay long,
Concerning his quest, he could find no one
Who would tell him the truth; on the contrary, they took him for a madman!
Most of those who heard him, made fun of him.
However, the count continued searching in good faith;
He suffered everything peaceably; he never answered except politely.
Then he left them, following his random path,
Until he came by chance to Calabria.

lg.head: Laisse 52
lg.l: Count Huon rode into Calabria,
Imploring God as he went, confessing his sins;
He beat his breast because of the many sins that lay upon him;
He never ceased reciting every prayer he knew.
He began the Magnificat animam domine,
And he chanted and recited it to the very end;
Not even in the face of distress or danger did he ever stop,
So that he chanted it well, since had so much time to do so.
If anyone wishes to recount the life he led
Since he had left his land, leaving everything behind,
He must tell of the great abstinence to which [Huon] subjected his body;
Whatever difficulty or ease he experienced,
He never ate more than once a day:
Some bread and some water, no other food did he have,
And whatever bitter wild herbs he found
That might sustain him. He prayed to Jesus himself
That He be his succor wherever he might go,
And that He not hold against him all the things he had confessed.
He knew well it was impossible that he not carry on,
For he would never be forsworn so long as men were alive (so I believe).
Then he rode onward and wandered for a long time
Until he came to Calabria, and then he stayed for a while,
For he found no information about the thing he sought,
Or anyone who said he had seen it. But many affirmed
That if he were willing to go to Athens, to that faraway land,
There where the sages lived, where there were many wise men,
There was great hope that he would be able to find out
Everything he was seeking if anything ever were to be found.

lg.head: Laisse 53
lg.l: Huon heard what they said, and agreed wholeheartedly with them;
So he thanked them, and took leave of them.
He came straight to the port, but he didn't dally there,
As he wished to speed himself on his way and to embark on the sea.
He found a galley at the entrance to the port
That was about to leave to rob and pillage
As was their custom(there were many of them pledged together
Who lived on nothing other than evil deeds.
When they saw the count coming up the road,
The group's master remarked to them:
"We will have gained some excellent merchandise
With this one coming up who will be worth a lot to us."
Then to the count he said, "Friend, what do you seek?"
And Huon answered, "For God's sake, I would beg you
To allow me to come up on your swift ship,
Along with my horse, which I have brought with me.
If you want goods or some other payment,
I will pay you as much as you like;
I want to get to Athens, the amazing city."
And the other answered, "That suits us very well!
Come on board, for you have arrived
So early that we have a good wind."
So Huon boarded and thanked them and God.
May God watch over the count, who was very badly lodged!
If He does not provide for him, his life will soon be over,
For each one of them has promised and sworn
To cause his death before the day is over!

lg.head: Laisse 54
lg.l: The good count has gone on board the galley;
He called much upon God the Father,
That He be an aid to him, a faithful believer.
Then he made the sign of the cross, and asked to speak to the ship's pilot.
"Friend, now plot your course so that we move swiftly forward;
I know you know how to make good time on the water.
I place my confidence in God and in you; now take good care of me."
And the other answered, "Will we be well paid?"
"Yes, brother, indeed, as much as you wish."
"Then leave everything up to me,
Since we have good wind and weather,
In no time we will have advanced so quickly,
That before the third day is over and done,
We will be there where you wish so much to go."
The count in reply thanked him for everything.
He provided for his horse in the usual way.
In the meantime he believed himself completely safe,
And the ship moved swiftly along.
But now when the ship had moved rather far away from the port
And the wind had fallen, those who had evil hearts
Wanted to betray everything they had sworn.
So they lowered the sail and stopped the galley,
And ran to seize their arms, then they cried out to Huon:
"Put down all your arms, you seem to be a madman!
We don't trust you or your supposed goodness;
When we want our pay upon arrival at the port,
You will not run away there for that reason.
Give us all your wealth(we'll put you in our brig,
And it will truly go well with you if you ever escape alive."

lg.head: Laisse 55
lg.l: When Count Huon heard the fierce things they said,
He answered, "What in the world are you thinking?
Have I not just promised payment to all of you together?
Have no doubt whatsoever, [my] lords, about it;
I will never default, by God Almighty."
But they answered him, "We will not release you for anything.
Put down your weapons and pay us!
If it so happens that you don't, things will go quite differently for you."
Once Huon was well aware of their intentions,
And that it was useless to try to soften them at all,
He said to them, "The entire payment will be made to you;
Making a show of force will gain you nothing."
At this response, several of them lost control,
And they began to attack him, but he knew well how to defend himself
Like a man of prowess and valor.
He hastened toward them; he lost no ground at all;
In very little time it went so badly for them
That the strongest among them was completely dismayed.
They cried out their affliction at this attack,
For so many were killed, at least two hundred,
And he would have done the same to the rest of them.
But the baron thought to himself that he could come to harm,
As he knew absolutely nothing about the sea;
By their navigation he would be carried to safety.
So he held back and drew himself back to one side
And called out to them, "What are you doing, you scoundrels?
I never thought to have such a fright;
I begin to pity you greatly, however,
Not that you are worth it, for you are worse than a serpent;
Truly you have betrayed your promise.
I should not believe anything you say from this time forth,
But basic goodness tells me otherwise:
If you wish to have peace, I will give it to you willingly;
Or indeed, if you prefer war, I cannot do otherwise than grant you that."
When these knaves heard his speech,
They cried out to him as loudly as they could,
"Do whatever you wish with us, good sir;
We declare ourselves your men from this very moment,
And swear to you absolutely on all that is holy
Never to deviate from your command."
And Huon answered, "Will you thus swear to me
To bring me in good faith and loyalty
Straight to the port of Athens, and right away?
I neither ask nor expect anything else from you;
Then you can leave as soon as it is safe
And go wherever you wish, entirely free."
And they thanked him and then swore an oath.
Then they raised the anchor and set forth on the sea,
Sailing over the waves as speedily as they could.
Still, they were sorrowful over the death of their friends,
Whose bodies they had to throw into the sea;
Never ever did they speak of them again.

lg.head: Laisse 56
lg.l: Now Count Huon is moving fast over the sea;
[The sailors] transport him, with pale and deferential face.
Thenceforth they sailed with all due speed.
The count with the noble heart was eager [to arrive]
So long as he was in the hands of these wild people.
He said he would have no rest until his life there ended.
But he continued to pray to the One who rules the world
That He lead him to the port of the infernal people
In order to present his message, without any felonious thought,
On behalf of Charles Martel, whom France obeyed.
Then he raised his head, with its noble face,
"Who is the master among you, the one whom you obey?"
"What do you want, [my] lord? Tell your desire
To us, who are your servants without any ill intent."
Huon said, "What is your name, in the Christian faith?
Tell me about yourself; I want you to talk to me about it."

lg.head: Laisse 57
lg.l: "Vassal," said Count Huon, "Now hear what I have to say:
If you are caught up in evil doings, you will have a bad reward for it."
And the other answered him, "Fair sire, in the name of God, who sits on the high throne,
I will speak truthfully about the subject we must discuss."
He then explained their entire situation:
"Know that I am a sinner as much as any man in the world;
Of all the sins that we find these days,
I believe that they reign in me because of evil will.
We have lived this life for more than forty years:
All the scoundrels eventually come to me,
Both on land and on sea many people fear me.
I am called an evildoer, and my name is Samson.
I have two sons with me, Anseis and Guyon;
They have fierce faces, both born of women from Aragon.
We had little choice but to leave that realm:
We were banished when we killed a worthy man."

lg.head: Laisse 58
lg.l: "Ah, Samson," said the count, "You are leading a bad life!
You are ruined only because of your great sin.
Now behave like the brave man that you are and repent fully;
Turn to Jesus, the son of holy Mary.
You should beat your breast and, as one full of contrition,
Do a bit of fasting(God will then take care of you.
And find a good priest who will confess you.
If you would like then to accompany me,
I will most happily take you with me in the name of brotherhood.
Then I will love you always as I love myself.
And thus I tell you, there is so much power,
And goods, money, gold coins and possessions,
I am thinking of giving you more; more than in two and a half months,
A good galley could carry,
Many evil Saracens will produce this wealth
Because Christians are completely protected by me
If the men do not rise up in any foolish action against me,
Like the one you just attempted, out of your arrogance,
Which caused you to attack me even though you swore allegiance.
You act like brave men; get rid of your wrong way of thinking,
And repent! God will have pity on you.
Henceforth I will be your protector.
I will take you through this foreign realm,
And you will be completely safe, if God so decrees,
I assure you; don't think it foolish."
When the other had heard what Huon had to say, he bowed down with great emotion;
As he wept he fell to [Huon's] feet,
And said, "My lord, I thank you for this from the bottom of my heart;
We want nothing more than to answer your summons.
Moreover, we greatly regret our attack on you.
This we now understand well; and, yes, without indeed any deceit,
May God, the son of holy Mary, permit us
Not to lose our souls by this false path."
Then the count said, "We are indeed at peace."

lg.head: Laisse 59
lg.l: The count continued to speak to Samson:
"I know well something about your parentage;
I saw your father, who was no criminal,
Down at Carcassonne a good ten years ago; this we all knew(
He behaved like a truly worthy man.
He won great renown from that attack.
I counted on him and with good reason;
Many times we were companions in good faith;
Our separation caused many tears and laments.
He returned to his lands, I to mine.
Since then I have not seen him, but by the eyes in my head,
I urge you here and now to keep such company.
If the father was honorable, the son must be no less:
No man should stray from the virtue of his forbears for any reason.
Be then of stout heart; don't worry;
If you have committed crimes, repent,
And pray often to God and you will do well."
[Samson] said he would this with the best of intentions.
At these words, which they spoke and exchanged,
The galley reached port and they disembarked.

lg.head: Laisse 60
lg.l: Huon, the good count, disembarked onto solid land;
With a truly grateful heart he thanked God yet again,
And was doing it as always with weeping and tears.
Then he made the sign of the cross in the name of God the Creator.
He entered Athens feeling both buoyant and joyful,
Bringing Samson with him and many others from the crew.
The others he left to watch the horses
And the other arms and equipment of which there was much aboard.
He said that he would return to the ship, that he would not remain long.
They set off on their way and went so far that day
That he came to a place where there were lots of people all around.
He called to a wise man whom he saw before them;
He asked him with great courtesy, concerning what he was trying to do,
