"Where are you going, [my] lords? Tell me your intention,
For you certainly appear to be people keen to do well.
From this point forward there is nothing worth a penny
Either to eat or to drink, if you haven't brought it [with you]
Until you get to Le Mans or Nevers, that strong, established city."
Roger and the archbishop asked him why,
"What is the reason for this?" And he explained it to them,
"[My] lords," said the host, "about a league from here
You'll find a [body of] water that is very calm and wide;
On the other side of this water it is called Auvergne.
The lord who held it went away a long time ago,
[He was] the best knight ever born on earth.
But the one who sent him away is much blamed for it,
Because he thinks to have [the lord's] lady, and for this reason has sent for her.
But [this lord] is so courteous and valiant and wise,
That our emperor's intentions will be in vain."

lg.head: Laisse 185
lg.l: "Barons," said the worthy man, "you have heard me well;
Ever since the count of Auvergne left,
The lady, who is wise, constructed a plan such that
Throughout her lands, three and a half months ago,
There would be gathered into Auvergne
Bread and wine and foodstuffs and grain and hay,
So that the city and the castle might be provisioned.
And it was all done like that, no one opposed her.
Out of fear of the king everyone has fled.
The country all around has been burned up to the hills;
Not a creature is lodged there, I swear to you this is the truth.
All those who pass get provisions here;
And if you are not friends of the lady,
Be careful which way you go, [my] lords, this I beg of you;
You could well have something [happen to you] not at all to your liking."
The lord of Normandy answered [him] first,
And said to the host: "Listen, fair friend,
We are the ambassadors of the king in Paris;
You appear in good faith, and I have faith in you."
"[My] lords," said Richard, "what is your pleasure(
Go forward or go back?"
Both Roger and Saudin cried out their answers:
"We have no fear of any man alive on earth."

lg.head: Laisse 186
lg.l: Both Roger et Saudin yelled this time
Quite angrily at the lord of Normandy;
"Lord Richard, we know well your arrogance,
And about you, and about others, who don't love the king,
You have never ever valued his honor.
Whoever wants to go, let him go, since it won't matter,
For what we are supposed to do will be accomplished."
Afterward spoke the lord of Vermandois,
And Guy of Barcelona, who was wise and valiant,
And Duke Tholomeus, who was exceedingly courtly:
"Let's drop this quarrel now, for that would be better,
Because we know how things stand between you.
Everyone knows what's black or indeed violet or blue,
He who would accuse others would surely be very wrong.
He who accuses others gains no praise;
When we are armed to take up and enter a tourney,
Then we will distinguish the day from the night.
[But] let's leave [it] for that day; let's drop [it] at once."

lg.head: Laisse 187
lg.l: The quarrel was getting quite serious among our barons,
When count Gautier bowed before Roger;
"Lord Roger," he said, "I won't fail to tell you
That venom and antivenin don't go well together.
Loving and hating contradict one another.
There are here seven counts of ancient ancestry,
Each one holds his lands by noble right,
Among them there is never lying or trickery,
And there won't be [any] among us if it pleases the Son of Mary.
Let it be according to your pleasure concerning going or staying,
And if you wish otherwise, don't stay for our sake."
Then Henry, who was full of wickedness, spoke up;
He didn't say at all what he really wanted [to say]:
"Lord Roger," he said, "when a man chastises you,
You must love him for it, that would be courteous,
And he who does otherwise would commit villainy.
We are here in pleasant company;
These [companions] are right and I shouldn't fail to tell you
When you take the whole decision upon yourself."

lg.head: Laisse 188
lg.l: "Roger," said Morant, "he is completely right
When he leaves you [the decision] to stay or go."
"Indeed," said the archbishop, "and we recognize it."
"Indeed," said Saudin, "[if we return], we'll all return together."
The host called them: "Come now, gentlemen.
Load up, my friends, what's needed."
And they did it right away, without any delay;
Bread and wine and foodstuffs, cooked meat and fish.
"[My] lords," said the host, "I and my son
And everything I have here is at your disposal,
[For] I and my town belong to king Charles."
"Galleran," said Gautier, "and we are grateful."
They left the castle early, before dawn.
The host accompanied them all the way to Le Mans, to the river;
He escorted them to the other side and then they took their leave;
[The host] turned back and our group continued
The whole day long, until evening fell,
For they found no habitation or house,
Nor man or woman anywhere around there
Except for a chapel [...].

lg.head: Laisse 189
lg.l: Our group lodged inside the chapel;
They sheltered themselves as best they could that night.
As soon as day dawned, each one took to the road,
Looking this way and that all day long,
(For they saw no house or habitation anywhere there),
Saying to one another, "This is a great calamity.
In such a situation, in such a quandary, we'll shelter by the Flores,"
(Such was the name of that river).
There they drank and ate from what they had brought with them,
They talked about this and that;
They traveled by day, once dawn brightened,
For a long time just as the poem says.
As the sun descended, they arrived at the bridge.
Saudin spoke first since he recognized the porter:
"Galudin, sweet friend, come over here a bit.
We are messengers from France, whom the king sent here.
Once the countess knows this, I do believe she will be pleased;
Go find out. These men will wait for you.
The other answered him: "[My] friend, I won't fail
To take care of your wishes and of you if necessary."

lg.head: Laisse 190
lg.l: Galudin thus took off down the main street,
Until he came to the palace where court was held.
In the main hall built and decorated with gold,
He found the countess sorrowful and upset,
And the assembly of barons was silent and mute.
I'll explain to you why if you'll listen to me,
For that [very] evening a pilgrim had come,
Who told her news that had not pleased her:
That he had seen the count in Jerusalem,
And through his might alone the city had been conquered,
And the people baptized, and our faith adopted.
Then the people great and small wanted to proclaim him king,
That he take possession [of that land] of earthly splendor,
For out of love for [Huon] all of Syria would arise,
And Greece and Turkey and Salonica and Valdrue,
Vermandois, Valisars, and Tarsia,
Even the stout-limbed Olidans from Tartary,
Everyone would cross [the sea] to oppose the deceitful king.
"Either he will absolve you of the promise,
Or he will be destroyed and confounded,
And the crown of France will be rendered to you."
The count had an angry reaction to that;
[But] he refused very calmly.

lg.head: Laisse 191
lg.l: "[My] lady," he said, "just as I have told you,
The count refused the position and its benefits;
Two weeks later he took his leave.
Everyone was sorrowful and upset,
Most of them believe that he was lost at sea,
Because no further news was ever heard concerning him.
May God counsel him and those who are left behind."
"Alas," said the countess, "I have no more any desire to live,
When I have lost my hope and my lord."
She wrung her hands and pulled out her hair;
"Oh, knighthood, what has happened to
Great generosity and perfect honor,
The arm of justice and the tree of virtue?
The counselor of all counselors for the bereft betrayed,
Oh, Christianity, how [...]
Oh, wretched king, if only you had never been born!
Don't you remember, you wretched, wicked man,
Outside of Rome on the battlefield where you were struck down,
And your barons killed and thrown into disorder;
And the Auvergnat who engendered [Huon was] killed,
And the banners [were] struck down and your barons put to flight
Across the mountains and valleys and those craggy hills?
Not a single one of them would have remained
If it were not for Count Huon [strengthened] by the power of Jesus,
You would never have had any more honor on earth;
You have held on to your crown only because of God and my lord."

lg.head: Laisse 192
lg.l: Anyone who might have heard the lady express her sorrow at that time,
Couldn't have had a heart so hard as not to be moved,
[As she continued] saying, "Oh, alas, I have lost my lord,
For only because of me, a miserable sinner,
He who will return [too] late has gone away
And I will die languishing for him."
Then she fainted dead away in a sweat;
Her barons, with tears and weeping, helped her up again.
Throughout the hall there was such a great tumult
That everyone throughout the city, great and small, wept.
At that moment here was Galudin, crying out fearfully
Breaking through the crowd without stopping.
When he saw Ynide, who had lost all her color,
He greeted her properly [and] nobly for the love
Of the God of glory, the true Creator;
"[My] lady," he said, "there are ambassadors
Whom the great emperor has sent to you.
What do you command? State your will,
To let them in or not, I'll return [to do it]."

lg.head: Laisse 193
lg.l: "[My] lady," said Galudin, "what do you wish to command [me to do]?"
"Alas," said Ynide, "just let me be!
I'd rather die than endure any longer."
"[My] lady," said [...]
"Indeed," said Baudoin, "[my] lady, it must be done."
Both Teris and Gautier said exactly the same thing,
And Thomas and the others agreed.
In order to go meet them, properly honoring them,
Many men went out and mounted their horses.
They rode up to the gate without stopping,
Had it opened and had the drawbridge lowered.
The ambassadors entered within;
Saudin the traitor spoke up first:
"Barons," he said, "may God keep you from all harm,
Both you and those who love the emperor,
And may He totally confound villains and scoundrels!"
"Indeed," said Thomas, "and the evil advisors
Who inflict pain and suffering on others."
As these words were said, they rode to the square
To dismount, but then together with the knights
Climbed to the highest level.
Now you'll hear told and recounted
How one side argued with the other.
The very first one to speak was Roger,
Since he was the king's principal administrator.

lg.head: Laisse 194
lg.l: The ambassadors stopped in the great hall
In front of Ynide, whose head was covered.
Dressed in black, pious and virtuous,
There were hot tears [coursing] down her robe and gown;
The pilgrim had not yet left.
Now you'll hear the deliberation of [this] lamentable affair;
Roger, who had very great authority, began:
"That Lord of glory, from whom all good appears,
May He grant complete joy to everyone, young and old,
And most of all to the great king [here] on earth;
And to you, noble lady, and to all your family.
The emperor, who possesses this in torment,
Has sent us here and the reason is this:
[It is] out of love for your lord, whom he loves more than Orestes
[Loved] Calisor or the king of Guineste,
Or Achilles [loved] Patroclus of Floreste.
Indeed it is thus, he is making the truth known
By sending for you, entreating you with all his being
Solely in order to honor you, in the name of God the heavenly King.
You will be together with his wife and his daughter,
Part of [their] exalted company; I don't know what happens afterward.
This you will have, if it delights and pleases you,
Until the count comes back from this quest."
"I won't come," said the lady, "by [God's] highest majesty."

lg.head: Laisse 195
lg.l: After Roger, Teris spoke:
"Lady," he said, "the emperor of Paris
Has dispatched and sent us out of great love,
Only to honor both you and the marquis.
By rights he is obliged to do it, for [your lord] is his friend."
"[This last thing you said is] true," replied Ynide, "but [the first thing] is not at all.
One [thing] is white, and indeed the other gray."
To this comment replied Henry,
The one from Aubespine, a cursed scoundrel,
And Teris uttered nothing else.
"Lady," said the scoundrel, "your lord's honor
And that of mine as well cannot be disappointed.
By doing this, one might think that you hated him."
"Wretch," said the lady, "you're lying through your teeth,
For I love my lord more than the eyes in my head.
Whoever believed you would be foolish!
Go away, evil, vile man,
For no good ever comes from a base heart,
And if [something good] does come out, it immediately regrets [it].
We know well what your wishes are."
He retreated, distressed and embarrassed.
The next to speak was Belencer the marquis,
He was wise and courtly, humble and well-bred;
He spoke in good faith, without any bad intention.

lg.head: Laisse 196
lg.l: "Lady," said Belencer, "listen to what I'll say:
The emperor who has sent us in this way,
Sends [us] all the way here for you, [my] lady,
If you please. Indeed, I'll escort you back to France
Just until I deliver you to the king by the hand,
Afterward, if there is anything else, I don't know;
I truly believe that my lord will do you honor;
You'll be staying with his lady and his fair daughter,
You could never find a nobler companion
Than the queen who holds the world in her arms.
There you'll stay until [your lord] comes back,
For which reason [your] status and joy will double.
The king and all his friends will come to you;
I believe I speak rightly and don't know if you will take it wrong."
"Belencer," said the lady, "I'll say one thing to you,
That the words are separated from the music."

lg.head: Laisse 197
lg.l: Belencer fell silent and the lady as well.
Next Morant d'Hautefeuille spoke:
"Fair one," he said, "the king has the intention
To serve you as long as he lives.
He doesn't wish to separate you from the queen,
He wishes to honor you as much as her, together,
Because at the departure of your lord
Above all things he was begging this of [the king],
And my lord made a vow to him
To take care of you always as long as he lived.
Once you are in his household,
Together with the queen and her lovely daughter,
Such a [household] knows how to kneel and serve,
For it wouldn't take care of you alone;
You'll be more honored than any other person.
Lady, think about whether I speak the truth or lie."
Then he fell silent, looking very pious.
"Morant," said the countess, "and I'll say something.
Your lord speaks kindly, for which I send him thanks.
[But] I would be severely blamed by everyone,
When my lord is undergoing such hardship,
If I went entertaining myself with pleasures.
I would be very loathe that you or anyone else
Might in any way scorn me for this.
You have heard me clearly; I won't come at all."
Guy, who possessed Barcelona, replied to this.

lg.head: Laisse 198
lg.l: The lord of Barcelona was very wise;
"Lady," he said, "it is asserted everywhere in the world
That one must show reverence to the crown,
And every creature, horrible, bad and good
Must support the emperor, with [his] wealth or [his] person;
And anyone who does otherwise I don't believe is making a proper effort.
I say this for your sake, fair-faced lady,
That the emperor, on whom the whole world depends,
Has sent for you; and it seems dangerous to me
That you refuse [to come]. Where does this hostility come from?
The king is not some mercenary or lout;
This is unbelievable, by the body of Saint Anthony,
In good faith, may God be my witness!"
"Friend," said the duchess, "I do believe that only with great difficulty
Could one find in you anything not good,
For one can clearly differentiate the wheat from the chaff."
"Indeed," said Galleran, "and terce from nones."

lg.head: Laisse 199
lg.l: Galleran, the eminent count of Artois, spoke up:
"Lady," he said, "the Roman emperor,
By the advice of those you see here,
In the name of his honor and that of the marquis [your lord],
Requests that you come to France, to [his] glorious kingdom,
You and any [such] company that pleases and delights you.
You must stay with the queen and her daughter with the blond hair
For however many weeks and months [might pass]
Until the count returns from the king's mission.
He does it only to honor you, so I believe,
And out of love for the one whom good men praise.
Now come, my lady, for I believe you would be acting properly."
"Friend," said the countess, "you are in good faith,
But old tradition recounts a proverb:
'It's right to blow on one who gets hot'.
I say it for this reason: you're going to leave now;
You'll go away, [my] lords, and I'll remain here."
"Lady," said Tholomeus, "indeed it is praiseworthy of you
When you upset the order of the king!
Think, my lady, what could happen."
"Friend," said the countess, "I have been thinking about it for a long time,
And for that reason I have replied immediately without delay."

lg.head: Laisse 200
lg.l: Tholomeus fell silent and bowed his head.
Next spoke Hugo of Savine;
He addressed Ynide and said, "Oh, lady of the palace,
You know well that the king holds power over the world,
And can raise or lower [people] in earthly glory.
It is too astonishing, by the Virgin Queen [of Heaven],
That you aren't willing to carry out his wish and his intention.
What is the reason? Do you hate him?"
The rosy-cheeked lady answered,
"Hugo," she said, "you have me greatly under constraint
When you ask me the secret of my hatred.
Do you take me, friend, for a simple-minded girl,
Such that my eyes can't distinguish between the rose and the thorn?
I wasn't raised in the woods or in the forest,
But truly in Lille, in Brois or in Menine.
Indeed, my mother was neither blind nor cross-eyed,
But [rather] was born of Broces, daughter of the duke of Saline.
Her father was the lord of Flanders, up to the sea,
His court was esteemed from here to Salumine.
And I am the wife of the count who rules Unverise,
And who is lord of Brabant, of Auvergne and of Cassine,
And Roman senator because of his divine virtue.
He who reminds me of the pain of my distress does evil!
Now may death and I be very close cousins!"
Tears from her eyes spilled down her breast,
For will and sorrow ended mixed up together;
She could scarcely keep from falling down to the stone [floor] of the hall.
